stem: The intensive care nurse is managing a client with severe ARDS. Based on the documentation in the Respiratory Mechanics Log, match each ventilator strategy with the appropriate clinical objective.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
08:00: Client (48y/o male) with Multi-Organ Dysfunction Syndrome (MODS) and ARDS. 
08:30: High plateau pressures noted (> 35 cm H2O). 
09:00: Switched from traditional volume control to Lung-Protective Ventilation (LPV). 
09:30: Goal set for 'Permissive Hypercapnia' to avoid barotrauma.

tabs.title: Respiratory Mechanics Log
tabs.content:
StrategyCurrent SettingObjective
Tidal Volume4 mL/kg (Initial 10)Reduce lung stretch
PEEP15 cm H2OAlveolar recruitment
Plateau PressureTarget < 30 cm H2OAvoid VILI
PH Goal7.20 - 7.30Permissive Hypercapnia

tabs.title: ABG Stats
tabs.content: pH 7.24, PaCO2 58, PaO2 62, HCO3 24. P/F Ratio 68.

columns.text: Accepting Acidosis to Avoid High Pressures
Maximizing surface area for gas exchange

rationale.correct: Low tidal volumes (r1) prevent the lungs from over-stretching (volutrauma/c1). Permissive hypercapnia (r2) is the intentional acceptance of high CO2/low pH to avoid using dangerous pressures (c2). High PEEP (r3) creates an 'Open Lung' by recruiting alveoli (c3). Maintaining plateau pressures < 30 (r4) is the hallmark of preventing barotrauma (c4).
clinicalPearls: Traditional ventilation (10-15 mL/kg) is LETHAL in ARDS.
Lungs in ARDS are described as 'Baby Lungs' because only a small portion of the lung is actually functional/flatable.
Permissive hypercapnia is contraindicated in patients with high intracranial pressure (ICP).

questionTrap.trap: Believing that the nurse should increase the RR in response to a CO2 of 55 in an ARDS patient.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: If the goal is 'Permissive Hypercapnia', a high CO2 is expected and accepted as long as the pH doesn't drop too low (< 7.15-7.20).

mnemonic.title: Protect the Plate
mnemonic.expansion: Keep the **Plateau** pressure under **30** to protect the lung plate (parenchyma).
